Keeping your boost tubes and hoses in peak condition at all times is absolutely essential because failing to do so puts you at risk of boost leaks. You could find yourself with a damaged thrust bearing that requires a full replacement. By taking the time to routinely inspect your turbocharger set-up, replace hoses and tubes when needed, and make sure that everything’s nice and clamped, however, you can drive worry-free!

Turbo tip #3: Partner your turbo installation with an oil change and filter replacement

When a new turbocharger is installed, most truck owners are oblivious to the fact that they run the risk of air restrictions and oil contamination issues that result from old, dirty filters. Simply by replacing your engine oil, swapping out your engine filter, and replacing your air filter, you can prevent any problems from popping up!

NAME: Towing Your Diesel 101: 3 Simple Tips For Beginners
CONTENT:
It’s no secret that Diesel engines are designed to generate more torque, which is why their commercial and heavy-duty trucks are often the cream of the crop in the auto industry for its towing and hauling capabilities. 

Even with an impressionable engine that can guarantee a stress-free drive, there are still critical steps you need to know to ensure a safer towing experience. With that in mind, the tips below should help you steer away from potential mistakes and roadblocks along the way: 

 

Tip #1: Hook It Up Using the Right Hitches and Ball Size

The first step is to hook the two-strap or chain securely to each end of your vehicle to attach the load. Keep in mind that the chains should never drag on the ground, so be sure to adjust it to the appropriate length. 

As for the hitches, there are different levels of weight that vary according to what you need to tow, such as the following: 

  • Class 1: Up to 2,000 pounds
  • Class 2: Up to 3,500 pounds
  • Class 3: Up to 8,000 pounds
  • Class 4: Up to 10,000 pounds
  • Class 5: Up to 12,000 pounds

 

The weight of the trailer will also influence the ball size, wherein it should always exceed the capacity of a loaded trailer. Keep in mind that the hitch ball is an integral safety gear as it supports some of the trailer’s weight, which helps maintain control over the truck. 

 

Tip #2: Always Consider the Trailer Load Balance 

Ensuring that the trailer load is stable is crucial to a smooth-sailing ride carrying a massive weight. It can help keep the vehicles in proper alignment, making each movement predictable, especially when handling curves or corners. 

 

With that in mind, most manufacturers recommend that at least 60 percent of the weight of the trailer’s load should be spread with the trailer’s front half to maintain a balance. 

 

Tip #3: Always Opt For Safety Chains 

Even with a highly secure attachment between the ball and tongue of the truck, opting for safety chains can boost security by ensuring the trailer and hitch remain fastened together. In that regard, don’t forget to use the right length that is enough to handle turns and twists without hitting the pavement.  

 

The Bottom Line: The Importance of Choosing the Right Equipment and Weight Compatibility When Towing a Truck

The massive amount of torque in Diesel engines enables it to smoothly carry heavy loads, other trucks, or trailers across hills and gain speed even with a forceful headwind. The best part is that its impressive turbocharge is matched with an equally efficient fuel economy. 

 

Towing a trailer and other heavy cargo requires plenty of practice and preparation, but the tips above should clue you in on the basics to ensure you can tow away without running into trouble on the road.

NAME: 5 Reasons You Should Invest In Diesel Fuel Additives
CONTENT:
Poor quality diesel fuels at gas stations don’t always follow the best standards for gas, which creates different complications to your vehicle due to fuel-related issues. These can range from minor issues like slow acceleration idling time to more severe damages like fuel icing and poor lubricity. Using a diesel fuel additive keeps you from dealing with these problems while it also provides several benefits for your engine’s shelf life.

 

The advantages of using high-quality diesel fuel

If your car is suffering from excess smoke or fuel, the common culprit may be the presence of poor diesel fuel. Investing in a high-quality diesel fuel additive will prevent you from suffering the different issues that it can give to your vehicle.

In this article, we will share five reasons using a diesel fuel additive can help prolong your diesel engine’s life span:

 

It lubricates your vehicle's fuel injection system

One essential requirement for newer emissions regulations is ultra-low sulfur diesel fuel. However, these policies also result in hydrodesulfurization (HDS) that makes diesel fuel lose its lubricity.

 

Know that lubricity is vital in preventing your engine’s components from wear and tear. Having low levels will cause your high-pressure pumps and fuel injectors to have a shorter service life. Fuel additives, such as XFP’s Diesel Power Plus, prevents the issues of low lubricity by coating the fuel system’s internal parts to produce less friction for better fuel flow.

 

It cleanses your fuel systems and injectors

Fuel additives contain a formulated detergent to aid in the flushing out of hard deposits that build up in your tank. Decarbonization, in particular, helps in repairing common issues, such as engine hesitation and rough idling. By removing the excess carbon, your engine will be able to improve diesel performance while contributing to better fuel efficiency at the same time.

It improves cetane ratings

Diesel engines require a specific cetane number (CN) to operate correctly. This can range from a rating of 40 – 45 for American brands compared to global numbers that can reach up to 55.

In many states, the ASTM D975 dictates that diesel fuel standard be set at 40. 

Modern diesel engines run at their best with a value above 48 for maximum efficiency. Fuel additives can increase an engine’s cetane to increase horsepower and start-up speeds while it reduces emission volumes and provide smoother transitions from idling to acceleration.

It reduces smoke while increasing fuel economy

A vehicle’s CN is a measure of its engine’s combustion efficiency. The higher the number is, the better chances that fuel droplets that land on the combustion chamber produce power. Higher chances of fuel-burning lead to fewer instances of smoke production. This doesn’t only reduce your volume of exhaust that your vehicle generates, but it also gives better fuel mileage per tank.

 

It prevents fuel icing and freeze-ups

Diesel fuel tends to freeze up during cold seasons. The low temperature causes the fuel filters to be plugged with wax and ice. Although this is only a minor inconvenience, it can cause significant permanent damage to your engine if left unattended or unused for a long time.

Diesel fuel additives are excellent solutions to prevent icing in your tanks because tailor-fit formulas, such as the XDP Polar-D Winter Formula, can keep your engine warm to prevent your fuel from freezing during cold seasons.

 

Conclusion

Improving your engine’s life span is necessary to make sure that you get the most mileage out of your vehicle. You should remember that the best way to deal with auto problems is by preventing your car from experiencing them in the first place.

Replace the fuel filters

A fuel filter purifies the fuel that powers the engine. When pulled into the engine, the fuel will also carry any debris and particles that might be present with them. Without a filter, the particles can cause a lot of damage to the engine. 

As the filters keep debris and particles out of the engine, they can be clogged over time. This means that, eventually, you will have to replace them. Note, however, that not all filters are alike. How do you do this? The best thing you can do is to replace the coolant in the system once in a while. That makes the engine cooling system gets to work with clean and efficient coolants, ensuring that it can effectively keep the temperatures in check.

Install an adjustable fuel pressure regulator

Many vehicles today come with what is known as a fuel injection system, also called FIS. The FIS, particularly in its fuel pressure regulator, controls how much fuel enters your engine, which can affect its performance.

If you have a FIS system in your vehicle, then we recommend replacing the regulator with an adjustable version. That way, you can accurately set how much fuel will be pumped into the engine. It also allows for any extra fuel to be sent straight back into the fuel tank, allowing for zero wasted fuel.

Keep in mind the tips we have shared and apply them to your vehicle. That way, you can ensure that your diesel engine is well-maintained and will last for the longest time possible. NAME: 4 Reasons You Always Need To Keep Your Fuel Tank Full
CONTENT:
One piece of advice that many drivers receive is to ensure that the fuel tank never runs empty. For one thing, an empty tank means a vehicle is pretty much useless. You won’t be getting far if your car is running on fumes.

However, an empty fuel tank can be more than just a hindrance. It can actually damage your vehicle that leads to permanent problems later on. To demonstrate what we mean, here are the reasons you need to ensure your car’s fuel tank is never empty:

 

1. Prevent condensation

Condensation takes place when cold water vapor comes into contact with a warmer surface. The same thing can happen in your tank, particularly in the space that is not occupied by fuel. This can lead to moisture that can damage the components and prevent your car from running optimally, something that is further aggravated in cold weather where the the moisture can freeze.

 

2. Prevent fuel pump failure

The electric fuel pump motor needs gasoline because it acts as a coolant to ensure proper operation. When your gas tank is low, the pump can suck in air, which can generate heat. Over time, the heat can cause wear to your fuel pump.

This can lead to several problems that affect the performance of your vehicle. One, you might find it difficult to get your engine going. Two, it can impede fuel efficiency, lowering your car’s expected mileage. Three, it can increase the chances of your engine overheating, causing your car to stall while you are on the road.

 

3. Prevent rust & dirt

Dirt and rust can get trapped in your fuel tank, and when you’re running low on gas, these harmful elements can build up and block your fuel filter. When this happens, you’re looking at potentially costly repairs that you want to avoid. 

Moreover, the dirt can go into the fuel filter. When your engine shakes when you’re sitting idle in your car, it could signify a build-up of dirt in your fuel filter. You can also find it difficult to start your vehicle or it might not start at all. 

 

4. Prevent unnecessary accidents

Can you just imagine getting into an accident or finding yourself trapped in the middle of the night because you ran out of fuel? Allowing your fuel tank to run low is not practical, especially if your frequently traverse empty roads.

Keeping your fuel tanks full as much as possible is also for your safety and protection. You must remember that when an engine dies abruptly, brakes and power steering can also be lost, preventing you from using you car safely should you manage to get it to run.

 

Conclusion

There are many reasons you may avoid filling your tank when it’s low. It could be that you’re running late or just too busy to remember. On the other hand, others do not fill their gas tank as a way to save more money. 

The thing is, saving time and money this way will cost you more in the future when you encounter issues with your fuel parts or, worse, when you get into an accident. The next time your tank is low, fill it up right away.

NAME: Intake Systems: A Guide to Cold Air & Short Ram Intake
CONTENT:
Buying an intake system to replace your car’s factory component will lead you to choose one of two main options together with the various mods and attachments to improve your car’s performance. Before you buy an intake system for your car, you need to decide whether you’re looking to install a cold air or a short ram intake. Keep in mind that each one has its pros and cons depending on the variability that you’re looking for in handling your vehicle.

 

Comparing the two intake systems

Knowing the difference between the two systems will allow you to make a better judgment of whether one or the other is more effective to use as an intake system for your vehicle. In the sections below, we will share a quick guide to the differences between cold air and short ram intake:

 

Cold air intake 

This system is mainly used to draw in cold air, which is where the name comes from. It’s placed in the car’s fender or around the engine, depending on its design and fitment. The system includes several pipes, which makes it more expensive and more challenging to install in a vehicle. Since this intake has more piping bends, manufacturers need to ensure that air/fuel ratios remain at a safe level.

With a cold air intake system, your car is less likely to be bothered by the presence of a radiator fan’s heat. However, some setups place the system near the radiator fan so the heat might be sent right into your intake system, which can cause poor performance on your vehicle’s handling.

 

Short ram intake 

These intakes are one of the more popular options for intake systems in the market since they can comfortably replace your vehicle’s factory intake with a smoother pipe and an open-element air filter. In terms of price, short ram intake systems cost considerably lower compared to cold air systems. Since it’s a perfect fit to replace the factory intake system, it’s easier to install and requires less horsepower and torque to operate.

Some manufacturers don’t include the option for cold air intake systems, which makes the short ram a default option for truck owners. Besides incompatibility with the design, some vehicles don’t require the additional power of a cold air intake as it could also decrease power due to its mass airflow (MAF) sensor.

 

Investing in intake scoops

When it comes to intake scoops, the judgment on its effectiveness relies on its design and placement. Some race cars have intake scoops that receive air from the bottom of the vehicle or the front of the bumper. This allows for more cool air to reach your air filter, which generates higher levels of power. Ram systems work in the same principle by directing air to your filter, which essentially turns your regular factory intake into a cold air intake with the addition of intake scoops.

 

Knowing heating and ventilation options

Intake systems in the market offer heat shields to block off engine heat to prevent them from reaching a short ram’s open-element air filter. However, not all models have this option. Some short ram intakes systems include a performance airbox. This addition promotes a higher airflow compared to a stock airbox and allows your vehicle’s air filter to receive higher volumes of air. Air boxes are excellent for engine bays that can’t have a heat shield installed or deal with the issue of hot air delivered through the engine compartment by a radiator fan.

 

Conclusion

Besides looking at the intake system you’ll use, you also need to be wary about its materials. Heat soak occurs when your intake piping heats up too much that hot air is sent through your engine, decreasing its performance. A well-made intake system is built from sturdy materials like aluminum, which prevents it from sending hot air by having a durable piping system.

NAME: 5 Correct Ways to Break in Your Brand New Car - Our Guide
CONTENT:
When you get a brand new car, you might be tempted to drive it around too much, too fast, too soon. After all, this is your worthwhile investment, and you have all the reasons to get excited. However, pushing your diesel engine way too hard and putting your car parts under excess strain early on could cause repercussions. 

Manufacturers recommend breaking in your new car to maintain a good fuel economy, ensure that the moving parts work together properly, improve small diesel engine performance, and potentially extend your vehicle’s lifespan. It involves driving and maintaining it in a specific way using certain techniques for some time to help it adjust and operate to various driving conditions. 

Here are some techniques to break in your new car properly:

 

Accelerate gently

Flooring the accelerator of your vehicle aggressively can be tempting. It’s normal to want to discover what your car is capable of, especially when it is brand new. However, doing so can put your cylinders and engine oil to extreme pressure. It is best to accelerate gently, to ensure smooth engine performance.

 

Maximize your safety when driving

Breaking in your brand new car requires giving not only your engine time to fully adjust but also the various parts of your vehicle to settle in, which includes your brakes, tires, and suspension. Therefore, you need to drive as carefully and as cautiously as you can, especially for the first 200 miles. Your car parts will start to fully bed in and work better together after at least 1,000 miles.

 

Prevent your engine from pushing too hard

Forcing your engine to the red line can push your cylinders and piston rings to their limits. To ensure safety and prevent any damage, drive only up to 4,000 RPM in the first 1,000 miles of driving.

 

Give your engine enough time to warm up

Driving your brand new car for short trips is a bad idea because cold engines have to work harder. What you can do is to use your new vehicle only when you are going on a long drive to avoid putting a strain on your oil delivery cycle. Doing this also ensures that your engine has been given enough time to warm up. 

 

Avoid towing heavy loads

 

Getting a new car might mean that you can now go on road trips with your friends and loved ones more conveniently. You might feel excited to finally travel and hit the road along with your travel trailer, but you must keep in mind that towing heavy loads on your brand new car will put added strain on your engine. It is best to give your engine some time to adjust and hitch up your caravan only after 1,000 miles of driving.

Conclusion

Driving your car fast on an open road might be one of the best feelings ever, but this can pose potential problems over time if your vehicle is brand new. To ensure optimum engine health, make sure to give your car enough time to adjust to everyday driving conditions by breaking it in.

NAME: 4 Signs There's Something Wrong With Your Car's Turbocharger
CONTENT:
Of the most sought after yet most misunderstood parts of any car, the turbocharger must be on top of the list. If you do not know what a turbocharger (turbo) is, it is a device that utilizes turbines to pump the engine full of compressed air to maximize the engine's efficiency. With that said, the turbocharger is also one part of the car that is likely to run into problems.

If you have a turbocharger installed, you must know the signs of a problematic turbocharger to ensure that you get it fixed as soon as possible.

The boost gauge does not work

Many turbocharger installations come with a boost gauge that will help you track how much power you are receiving when the turbo is active. However, if you find that the indicator either does not display the proper readings or that the gauge does not respond at all, it could be either a problem with the turbo or the boost gauge itself. Either way, send your car in to have the turbocharger checked thoroughly.

The turbocharger makes an unusual sound

If you have been driving with a turbocharger for a while, you will know how it typically sounds when active. This means that the moment it makes weird noises, you will be able to notice it immediately. 

If you catch your turbocharger making unusual sounds when active, have it checked. If you hear a loud whining noise from the turbo, then you will absolutely have to send the car for a fix right away. There could be a problem with the turbine or something related to the turbo that could potentially damage other parts of your car.

The exhaust smokes blue or grey

Older cars will generally produce smoke the moment they start or as they run due to dirty filters and the like. However, if you notice smoke coming out only when you step on the pedal to accelerate or see a smoke plume when you start the car, it might be because your turbocharger has a problem.

Often, the cause of this smoke is due to a crack in the turbine that causes oil to leak into the exhaust. This fluid eventually gets heated and emitted as smoke. 

The engine warning light is on

If the engine warning lights light up, this could mean that something is wrong with your turbo. We say "could" because the engine's diagnostic system covers a wide range of problems. 

For that reason, when you do see the light go on, you will need to bring the car in for further analysis and testing to locate the source of the issue.

Conclusion

If you discover any of the problematic signs above, then you need to send your car to a mechanic and have it checked right away. Even if it is not the turbocharger's problem, it does not change the fact that there is something wrong with the car and that you need to have it fixed. Failure to do so can put you at risk of requiring a more expensive repair job as the problem goes bigger. More importantly, the problem can pose a danger to your safety as well as that of others on the road.

Thankfully, avoiding the all-too-common mechanical problems and spoiling your driving experience simply entails being aware and watching out for all the signs before misfortune makes a visit. 

If you’ve been meaning to stay aware at all times along with making sure that your truck runs smoothly, here’s everything you need to know about bad fuel injectors, what causes them, and how you can avoid them entirely: 

The basics: what do your fuel injectors do, and what causes them to go faulty?

Generally speaking, fuel injectors are entrusted with the responsibility of precisely delivering a controlled amount of fuel to your engine at the right times for efficient combustion— which is the foundation of smooth driving experiences. Through the use of electronically-controlled valves, the injectors supplement the engine’s cylinders at spray rates and frequencies that span for fractions of a second.

In most cases, these parts can fail over time due to a lack of regular maintenance which leads to clogging and the development of faults. Over time, these underlying problems can exponentially grow in magnitude and cause a domino effect of issues that will end up tearing your engine up inside-out. 

What signs you need to watch out for

Every diesel truck exhibits the same symptoms of faulty fuel injector systems that any driver needs to watch out for. Fortunately, these very signs are distinct and can be spotted easily with a minimal amount of awareness: 

Your check engine warning light is on

One of the clearest signs that your fuel injectors need to be checked out right away is when your check engine warning light begins to pop up on your dashboard. For most cases, this light will only come on if an injector isn’t working as well as it should— which causes a signal that’s sent to the ECU and relayed to the dashboard. 

Your engine is stalling

Another clear sign that your fuel injector needs to be replaced is any present sign of engine stalling. When it comes to stalling engines, the experience of having random cuts is caused by an insufficient amount of fuel being supplied to the cylinders— which is then picked up by the ECU and acted on by intermittent on-and-off sensation in the engine itself. 

You’re experiencing constant misfiring

For most engines, misfiring and faulty fuel injectors go hand in hand as pops and bangs can only be caused by improper injection rates and broken systems. The symptoms of misfiring and vibrating engines are mainly rooted in clogs or blockages in the nozzles of the injectors, this throws off the fuel-to-air ratio off entirely— leading to imbalanced combustions and drops in acceleration!

Conclusion

When it comes to any kind of diesel truck or engine, it’s essential to brush up on vital knowledge about fuel injectors, along with what causes them to go faulty. By spotting the warning signs quickly, you’ll be able to avoid costlier repairs down the line and keep your engine running in the best shape possible at all times!

NAME: Cold Air Intakes: What They Are & What Benefits They Give
CONTENT:
Have you ever considered installing a cold air intake for your vehicle? If not, you should do so! It provides a massive boost to your engine's performance, effectively giving more power to your car and improving your driving experience. Nevertheless, know that there are many improvements you can make to your car, and installing a cold air intake is just one of them.

If you’re unfamiliar with what a cold air intake is, below is a quick guide on what they are and what benefits they have to offer.

What is a cold air intake? 

Put simply, a cold air intake (also known as CAI) is an assembly part that allows fresh air from the outside to enter directly to the engine. This provides the driver with more oxygen to light up fuel, pumping the car with even more power.

This type of air intake is labeled as "cold" because the air filter is moved out from the engine to another spot, such as the fender area. This allows cold air to enter the engine, as opposed to warmer air with the intake near the engine. For the uninitiated, colder air typically means more oxygen. As a result, the engine can enjoy plenty of oxygen to keep burning fuel because the entire installation allows for uninterrupted airflow.

What are the benefits of a cold air intake?

Know that there are many benefits to installing a CAI into your vehicle. Here are a few that you should know: 

1. It improves mileage

The biggest benefit of installing a cold air intake in your car is that it helps improve the mileage by a significant margin. This is because––thanks to the burst of oxygen––less fuel is required to turn the pistons. Without a CAI installed, however, your engine becomes deprived of oxygen. While it will still run, it will suck up more fuel to compensate for the lack of oxygen to successfully light up the chamber to turn the pistons. 

Once you have the CAI installed, your miles per gallon improve significantly. In addition to that, you save plenty of money that would have been spent on fuel, effectively allowing the CAI to pay itself off in the long run in terms of cost saved. 

2. It boosts acceleration

If you test two cars, one with CAI and the other without, you will feel the difference in terms of the acceleration. The car with the additional part will accelerate much quicker because it allows for a sudden burst of air to fill the engine when required.

3. It enhances engine roar

Do you love the sound of a roaring engine? If so, then you must consider installing a cold air intake. While a cold air intake is not designed to produce any sound, the rush of air entering the engine adds an enhanced roar that will satisfy any motorhead.

Conclusion

If you are a car enthusiast who wants to add more performance to your engine, create a satisfying roaring engine sound, or save money on gas, installing a cold air intake can do you wonders in all three aspects. While it is an aftermarket upgrade and costs some money initially, it is one of the most cost-efficient upgrades you can ever do. Plus, CAIs are easy to maintain. With just some soap and water, you can keep your air filters clean and your engines running smoothly.

NAME: Part Replacement: Choosing an Exhaust System for Your Truck
CONTENT:
Truck manufacturers often leave lots of room for additions and improvements to a truck’s horsepower and torque. This is why the built-in exhaust system is easily replaceable for a better system in the market, which gives truck owners more variability in their vehicles.

Your truck’s exhaust system is meant to divert reaction exhaust gases away from your vehicle’s controlled combustion. Choosing to install an aftermarket performance exhaust will allow you to free up more of your engine’s power while allowing for a quicker and more efficient way for exhaust gases to escape. As a result, this allows your truck to breathe better while maximizing your fuel usage at the same time.

Choosing the right exhaust system

Your truck’s factory exhaust system is meant to muffle as much sound as possible while still maintaining adequate power-robbing backpressure restricted by the exhaust gas flow from its pipelines. Aftermarket exhaust systems typically come in three different types that offer varying levels of less-restrictive performance depending on your preference.

In this article, we will share the three types of exhaust systems you can choose from:

1. Cat-back systems

Cat-back exhaust systems revert your catalytic converter’s components to your mufflers. These systems will include new tailpipes and mufflers, and can also have a mid-pipe, H-pipe, Y-pipe, or X-pipe, depending on your truck’s models.

Furthermore, they have an advantage over other systems due to their low-cost power gains. With considerably better fuel economy compared to other system types, it’s a formidable contender together due to the fact that these are emissions-legal systems because they incorporate your vehicle’s stock catalytic converter.

2. Header-back systems

Choosing a Header-back exhaust system will force you to replace everything from your truck’s header collector down to its tailpipes. By overhauling the entire exhaust system, you’ll make your truck have a larger pipe diameter for greater exhaust flow.

One significant drawback of this exhaust system is that it’ll be considerably expensive to install compared to a cat-back or axle-back exhaust system. You should only opt to retrofit your truck with a header-back exhaust system if you’re looking to upgrade your entire system of all its components.

3. Axle-back systems

An axle-back exhaust system is the most affordable system, mainly due to being the easiest system to install. It includes all the parts from your truck’s rear axle to the exhaust tip. Though header-back and cat-backs offer more power gains, it doesn’t cost nearly as little as what you’d spend if you choose an axle-back exhaust system.

Conclusion

Once you’ve decided on the type of exhaust system you want on your truck, you’ll then have to consider if you’ll go for a single or double exhaust system. Most people who prefer optimum performance choose the two-muffler look that’s paired with high-flow capacity with two separate exhaust passages, one for each back of their truck’s engine cylinders.

The key to choosing which system works best for your truck is finding the perfect balance of compatibility of the exhaust system to your model and your preference in handling your vehicle.

NAME: A Beginner's Guide to Intercoolers

In the world of trucks, there are many different sayings that drivers, mechanics, and manufacturers alike are bound to. Among all the different sayings and unbroken truths that continue to be applied, there’s one that you should know about: A turbocharged engine is only as good as the intercooler that’s paired with it.

An introduction to the supporting part

Best regarded as one of the integral components to any diesel engine, the intercooler is responsible for ensuring that everything else in the assembly runs as smoothly as possible.

Commonly mounted behind the grille and positioned between the engine and turbochargers, this vital component acts as an air-to-heat exchanger that seeks to lower the overall temperature of the compressed intake air. Beyond temperature regulation, this part—which is also known as a charge air cooler—also helps compress the oxygen taken in by the turbocharger into a more consumable form for the engine to ingest for better spooling.

Various forms worth taking note of

Generally, intercoolers come in different iterations that each come with their own set of advantages, disadvantages, and appropriate applications. Let’s go over each of them in further detail:


Standard intercoolers

For any truck that comes with a stock diesel turbo engine, it’s safe to assume that it also includes a stock intercooler that’s built to support baseline numbers and ensure smooth performance with a standard turbo.

In the case of most trucks, these air-to-air models follow a plate-style core design and three-inch-thick bar. Most truck owners end up keeping their standard intercoolers even if they have a few additional mods because they’re durable, simple to work with, and effective, all while saving a fortune.

Aftermarket intercoolers

As the desire to make more out of a diesel engine begins to settle in, turbo diesel truck owners typically pay attention to the system they use to keep everything under control as the mods pile up. This is where an aftermarket intercooler comes in.

Often seen as a non-negotiable for high-performance builds, aftermarket intercoolers are essentially standard options with greater capacities and capabilities to perform under pressure. What makes aftermarket intercoolers is that they feature larger cores, higher boost ratings, and upgraded construction to handle double, triple, or quadruple of a truck’s stock horsepower output.

Such components are especially important to include in any performance build because they provide enhanced cooling performance that helps prevent various problems, such as damaged valves, melted pistons, and wiped-out turbos!

Water-to-air intercoolers

In recent years, manufacturers have pulled out all the stops to provide consumers with more effective cooling systems that complement the higher power output brought about by performance parts. This is why parts like the water-to-air intercooler were produced.

High-performance builds, in particular, are set to benefit the most from this special intercooler as it works better with greater amounts of fuel and boosts that are both on top as such configurations merit excessive amounts of heat. With the help of an efficient water circulation system, however, rising temperatures can be mitigated without suffering much boost drop or warp.

Conclusion

Without an adequate intercooler installed, your turbo diesel engine may not be able to perform or last as long as it should. This is why it is important to know exactly which option should be in your engine bay. By taking this guide into consideration, you’ll be able to avoid any underlying problems and make sure that you’re getting your money’s worth during the build process!

NAME: How to Choose the Right Size of Turbocharger - Our Guide
CONTENT:
A turbocharged engine can produce more power, and for this reason alone, a lot of car enthusiasts switch to turbocharged engines. However, there are different sizes of turbochargers today because you can install them on any engine.

Whether you want to turbocharge your car or upgrade the existing one, keep in mind that the bigger isn’t always better when it comes to turbocharging. You might also be tempted to get the smallest turbocharger that meets your horsepower goals, but that’s not also the right solution.

So, the question is, how do you get the right size of turbocharger for your engine? Here are some tips:

Budget

It all begins with how much you’re willing to spend on it. If you don’t have enough funds, then there’s no point getting one and putting yourself in debt, right? That’s why before you buy a turbocharger for your engine, you need to assess your budget first.

Building a turbocharged engine doesn’t just involve the cost of the turbocharger itself. Other things come with it, such as the things that you will need for the installation.

Airflow

Engines operate an air/fuel ratio while gasoline contains a specific amount of energy, which means that you can make a direct correlation between airflow in CFM and horsepower. That said, you will be able to come up with the required airflow in cubic feet of air per minute because, in turbochargers, it’s not just about the boost.

Non-Turbo Airflow

Next, you need to calculate your engine’s non-turbo airflow in CFM. There are different ways to do this:

  • Use an online CFM-to-horsepower calculator
  • Take the engine to a dyno room and check its non-turbo airflow.

Boost Pressure Ratio

When you finally have your required airflow, it’s time that you divide it by your engine’s stock airflow to get the needed boost pressure ratio.

Turbo Map

A turbo map is a graph that contains airflow indexes to pressure ratio. It will give you a visual representation of turbo efficiency at a given pressure ratio and CFM. You can find this on a manufacturer’s selection of turbo maps.

Target Airflow/Pressure Point

Compare the required pressure ratio of your engine and airflow in CFM to compressor maps. Find one that puts your target airflow/pressure point in the center-to-upper-right-hand corner of your compressor’s maximum efficiency range.

Conclusion

The above steps will help you find the right turbocharger for your engine. It’s crucial that you search until you find a turbo that is spooled up at your torque-peak airflow and can maintain that PR through the horsepower-peak airflow of your engine.

Finding turbochargers can be tedious, but it’s an adventure for car enthusiasts who are looking to build their own engines. The search itself is a flurry of challenges that will keep you busy, along with the trial and errors that come with it. Even so, these will make the search worth it when you finally find the turbocharger that is right for your engine.

NAME: Our Guide to Choosing the Right Axle Ratio for Your Pickup Truck
CONTENT:
Shopping for a pickup truck can be challenging as it involves looking deeper into its parts to ensure your choice will meet your needs and lifestyle. From analyzing the motor, transmission, torque, driveline choices, and more, there’s plenty of specifications to think about.

Part of the details you can’t ignore includes the axle ratio options of a vehicle, which can make or mar your pickup truck’s torque and towing capacity. More than that, it also plays a pivotal role in indicating the vehicle’s fuel economy.

What is Axle Ratio and Why Does it Matter?

Axle ratio defines the number of rations of a vehicle. This includes the driveshaft, which is responsible for producing one rotation of the axle. The axle ratio plays a critical role since modern cars are made with intricate gears to promote different rates. Hence, the rear axle allows the wheels to rotate at different speeds to maintain excellent traction.

The axle ratio of a pickup truck is between three to four, which means the driveshaft will need to turn between three to four times to turn to achieve one rotation of the axle—with that in mind, knowing the axle ratio matters since it different numbers can have various impacts on the vehicle.

What are the Different Trade-Offs of Varying Axle Ratios For Your Truck?

A higher ratio, like a 3.9, for instance, gives drivers the ability to carry and pull heavier loads. However, the trade-off between a high axle ratio means you’re sacrificing fuel economy and speed.

On the other hand, a lower axle ratio promotes a higher fuel economy with lower torque and towing power. With that in mind, choosing the right axle ratio largely depends on your needs and how you plan to operate the truck.

Different Types of Axle Ratios For Trucks - What is a Standard Axle Ratio?

A standard axle ratio is generally the best, universal choice for most truck drivers, especially for those taking highway speeds as part of their route. Turning the axle faster means the driver can benefit from burning fuel, which saves on fuel since the engine doesn’t have to work double to turn the wheels.

This is an excellent choice for truck drivers who need to prioritize road speed or fuel economy. Meanwhile, front or rear-wheel-drive trucks also have varying ratios depending on the rear and front axle, but all-wheel drive trucks work better with similar front and rear axle ratios.

The Bottom Line: Choosing the Right Axle Ratio For Your Truck that Caters to Your Daily Needs

Choosing the right axle ratio for your truck depends on how much you need to tow and how fast you need to drive. You can quickly determine the average by assessing the weight of your daily cargo and finding how much money you can save when you achieve fewer miles per gallon.

NAME: 4 Maintenance Tips for Turbocharged Diesel Engine - Our Guide
CONTENT:
Diesel technology has come a long way in the automotive industry over the years. From ultra-low sulfur diesel to biodiesel, it has become more robust in that it caters to every vehicle owner's needs. The engine of a passenger vehicle proves to have addressed some drawbacks brought by its fuel counterparts, such as kerosene, home heating oil, and jet fuel. However, keep in mind that even a diesel engine needs proper maintenance to ensure its optimal performance and longevity.

In this article, we will share with your four maintenance tips for your turbocharged diesel engine:

1. Maintaining diesel engine turbochargers

The engine turbocharger plays a huge part in running your vehicle efficiently. However, you should make sure that your engine does not fail prematurely. Here’s what you can do as part of its upkeep:

  • Allow your vehicle to start up and remain idle for a few minutes, instead of stepping on the gas right away.
  • Allow your oil to reach all the parts of your engine, especially the turbo.
  • Use oil additives for your turbocharger and oil system to keep the lubrication at peak levels.

2. Using diesel fuel additives for biodiesel or USLD

When it comes to the use of fuel, there are two main types typically used: ULSD and biodiesel. No matter which one you use, know that the fuel additive is still needed. However, take note of the following:

  • Look for a water-demulsifying fuel additive (instead of those that burn the water) as it keeps the injectors flowing at full capacity.
  • Use a diesel fuel additive for fuel gelling, especially during colder months.

3. Changing diesel oil and filter

The lifespan of diesel engine oil depends a lot on the frequency of driving and its conditions. Know, however, that changing the oil should be a part of your regular upkeep. Here’s what you should do:

  • Follow the OEM-recommended oil change intervals to keep your engine humming and your vehicle running on the road as efficiently as possible.
  • Change your air filters as well as part of your maintenance, apart from changing the oil.

4. Choosing and using diesel coolant

As far as diesel coolant is concerned, there is a wide range of selection to choose from based on colors and specifications. Because of this, it can be quite a headache to find the right one. Here are a few tips you can follow:

  • Buy and use only OEM-recommended coolant.
  • Do not mix coolants as this can create a chemical reaction that may negatively impact your engine.
  • Never add water to your coolant because plain water does not disperse heat, and can only lead to bigger problems.

Conclusion

We hope that this article has helped you earn some valuable tips on maintaining your diesel engine turbocharger. Keep in mind the tips mentioned above, especially when using fuel additives for both biodiesel and USLD, changing the oil and filter, and choosing the coolant.

NAME: The Differences Between Lifting & Leveling - Our Guide
CONTENT:
As a truck owner, you want to know the best upgrades and the best methods to achieve optimal performance. Some of the most common upgrades you can get are either lifting and leveling upgrades. You may have heard of them before, but perhaps you’re not entirely sure about how these upgrades work. To help you better understand, here are the differences between lifting and leveling and which upgrade to get:

Lifting and Leveling

First and foremost, both of these methods are aimed towards raising the body of the truck. Doing so will enable you to fit larger tires and improve ground clearance. Both lifting and leveling kits are designed to reposition the body away from the axles.

Main Differences

While both kit methods are done to lift the truck, the exact measurements do vary. With a leveling kit, the body is lifted about two inches maximum at the front side. A leveling kit will make the front of the truck raised, and if you prefer a stock-style stance, you can pair it with a spacer block to raise the rear of the truck.

On the other hand, lifting kits raise the truck even higher than a leveling kit can do. Lifting the truck higher is made possible by modifying the suspension parts. For this, you can choose anywhere from two inches to ten inches in kit sizes. You can also go for custom lift kits if you prefer a much larger size.

In terms of ease, leveling kits are simple to install and less process is required to install them. That said, while lifting kits are more complex, they provide a more comprehensive array of features that leveling kits don’t have, including springs, shocks, control arms, and more.

Advantages of Leveling and Lifting

Leveling allows for larger tires that can be placed on all four corners, hence the term “leveling.” Most pickup trucks can hit the fender or bumper, especially during sharper turns. In this scenario, leveling is a good entry-level solution. Leveling kits are great at addressing the sagging issue of the suspension when something is added to the front of the truck. They keep the front of the truck leveled with the rear.

Lifting is primarily applied to allow the fitting of large tires. If you prefer to run with large wheels, you can use a lifting kit to help the vehicle run smoothly. Lifting kits are also great for raising all modifications that are generally in contact with the road when things start getting intense, especially for off-road sessions. In general, lifting kits are spectacular for giving large trucks better ground clearance.

Disadvantages of Leveling and Lifting

It should be noted that there are cons to any modification, which means you’re sacrificing something to achieve another feature. With leveling kits, you’re giving up style. Leveling kits aren’t as sleek and modern looking as lifting kits.

On the flip side, lift kits, while they look clean and modern, they don’t provide the same support that leveling kits do. Also, they can be extremely complicated to install.

Conclusion

Put simply, leveling kits are affordable and are more stable. They’re also very easy to install, which calls for fewer labor charges. Lifting kits are amazing in terms of design and additional functionality. While they may not be as stable as leveling kits, they provide access to other kits that compensate for that.

Dealing with the turbocharger

Here’s a tried-and-tested tip that is definitely essential if you want to keep your diesel turbocharger running smoothly: Let your truck warm up on idle.

Although this may sound simple, a surefire way to prevent any form of premature breakage is to let your vehicle start-up and remain idle for several minutes. The reason this is so important lies in the fact that warming up an engine properly allows it to get its own turbocharger to an optimal operating temperature without the risk of cracking. 

Additionally, a proper warm-up allows sufficient oil to reach all the various parts in your system so that everything is lubed up enough for proper operation, and this includes your turbocharger.

Additives options that are complete and compatible with the type of fuel that you use are absolutely essential because they help ensure that the contents of your tank perform their task in the most optimal way possible. From fuel gelling to octane maintenance, these nifty bottles of automotive supplements play a key role in keeping your turbocharged diesel engine running as it should for as long as possible.

Oil and filters

Another important detail to consider when maintaining your turbocharged diesel engine is that it heavily relies on regular oil and filter changes to run smoothly. Given that engines are essentially high-heat running motors, it’s important to ensure that everything is kept as clean and pure as possible so that nothing goes where it isn’t supposed to go. With regular oil changes and filter replacements, you can assure yourself of a safe and smooth drive every single time!

Conclusion

With the right maintenance tips in mind, you can keep your turbocharged diesel engine in tip-top shape at all times without worrying about any unturned stones along the way. Doing so is especially possible if you follow the guide given above!

NAME: Engine Maintenance Checklist for Truck Owners - What to Know
CONTENT:
Do you have a truck that you use on a regular basis? If that’s the case, then it’s important for you to know how to take care of it properly. Routine engine maintenance will help keep your truck in top working condition, saving you repair costs and unnecessary hassle. It will also ensure that the vehicle remains safe to drive, which is arguably one of the biggest priorities.

With that being said, how exactly should you maintain your truck’s engine? That’s what we’ll discuss in this article. Below, we’ll list down several tips for truck maintenance that you should follow.

Replace the engine oil and filter when needed

Let’s start with the engine, where most common truck problems arise. You’ll want to pay attention to two things here. The first is the quality of the engine oil, and the second is that of the engine air filter.

The engine oil is what keeps your engine running smoothly. It acts as a lubricant that reduces the amount of friction between the individual components. Over time, this oil gets dirty. It gets exposed to dirt that prevents it from performing optimally. If the problem gets serious enough, it could lead to damaged engine components, frequent overheating, and complete engine failure.

The air filter is similarly important. It acts as the engine’s first line of defense against dust, dirt, and other airborne contaminants. When this gets dirty, more these pollutants can make their way into the engine and cause it to malfunction. It also means that less clean air is able to enter the machine, robbing it of power.

A general rule of thumb for replacing these components is to replace the oil every 5,000 miles, and every 15,000 miles for the air filter.

Don’t forget the other car fluids

Let’s move on to the other important fluids in your truck. These include the brake fluid, the power steering fluid, and the engine coolant.

The brake fluid is what allows your brakes to function. Without it, you’d have no way of safely driving your vehicle. The biggest factor that contributes to its deterioration is moisture, which means you’ll have to replace it more frequently if you drive in wet conditions. Experts recommend changing your brake fluid every two to four years, depending on your usual driving conditions, the truck’s age, and several other factors.

The power steering fluid is what lets you maneuver your truck. It is directly connected to the power steering pump and rack, which means that if the fluid goes bad, the other expensive components can get damaged as well. This fluid usually gets dirty simply due to wear and tear. You will have to replace it every 50,000 miles. However, this figure will also depend on different factors.

Finally, the engine coolant does two things for your truck: one, it helps regulate the temperature of the engine, and two, it prevents corrosion. This, too, will break down over time, which could mean that your engine will start to rust and overheat at the same time. You will want to replace this every 30,000 miles.

Conclusion

Apart from these tips, you also want to check your engine regularly for any signs of damage. Corrosion is not normal in engines, and neither is the presence of strange noises when the engine is running. Make sure you pay attention to these signs so that you can fix the problem or have an expert do it for you.

Either way, it’s in your best interest that you make sure that your engine is running properly, so take regular maintenance seriously.

NAME: Our Beginner's Guide to Lift Kit Modifications
CONTENT:
Today, it’s quite rare to see a diesel truck in its stock form six months or so out of the dealership. With all the modification options available on the market, it’s no secret that many owners are now making their truck truly their own.

Regardless of whether it’s about a forged wheel replacement, snorkeler kit, or turbocharger upgrade, there will always be opportunities to customize and upgrade a truck. Out of all the different upgrade options available for all sorts of owners to enjoy, however, there’s one particular add-on that’s become much more popular: lift kits.

The popularity of the vertical upgrade

Coming a long way from its dirt track and monster truck origins, these upgrades can be seen in hundreds of thousands of different set-ups all over America.

The ideal truck in most people’s eyes is one that’s quite a bit above the ground, making it perfect for crossing through rivers, scaling rocks, and driving around in the dirt. With the help of a lift kit, you can bring your trucking dreams to life and give your rig the freedom it needs to stay true to its rugged and rough-and-tumble nature.

What the kit is comprised of

Generally, the intricacies of any truck’s suspension and chassis have led to the rise of model-and-manufacturer-specific kits that have the necessary components to best suit its needs.

In most cases, a standard lift kit includes strut spacers, lift blocks, and coil springs that are manufactured to best meet the needs of a particular make and model with the highest quality possible. For an added price, you can also get an extra set of trailing and control arms to make sure that your kit is properly set in place and is durable enough to last for many years.

It is worth noting that the components themselves entail having a few alterations to the steering geometry, drive shaft length, and brake lines of a truck to make sure that everything’s functional.

Is it a good idea to install your own lift kit?


Given the complexities of a truck’s system and all the technical know-how that come with installing a lift kit, there’s a small margin for error and many ways that you can mess up your vehicle. When you make the unwise decision to fit the kit in by yourself, here are a few risks that are bound to pop up sooner or later:

  • Unsafe and unbalanced handling on the road
  • Premature wear-and-tear on your suspension system and driveline— leading to even more costly replacement costs
  • Poor driving performance

Unlike standard cosmetic changes, lift kits are functional and aesthetic in nature, meaning that only an expert with a proper amount of engineering knowledge is capable of safely installing it.

Should you get a body or suspension lift?

When it comes to making a choice between both options, it’s important to note that the answer to the dilemma entirely depends on what you need.

For instance, body lift kits are purely for cosmetic purposes, such as adding bigger tires and getting a taller vertical look because it uses spacers to increase the height of the cabin. When put through rough conditions, such as rock crawling and cross-terrain runs, however, it’s safe to say that they may end up failing on you.

Suspension lifts, on the other hand, are geared towards hardcore truckers who need a dependable system that can hold up rugged off-road performance while providing a good amount of clearance. Performance suspension lifts, for instance, allow any driver to add wider tires and functional coil overs to provide a better experience and maintain balance at all times.

Conclusion

If you’re looking to add a significant cosmetic upgrade to your truck and improve its performance in handling various terrain and road conditions, then a lift kit will be best for your needs.

NAME: Suspension Lift Kit: What It Does & Why You Need It
CONTENT:
There are many vehicles that offer various forms of flexibility for a wide range of uses. For instance, Sport Utility Vehicles (SUVs) can be best modified with a handful of accessories to be used for various purposes. This is where a suspension lift kit comes into the picture. It is a form of modification done to raise the vehicle’s height and attain extra inches of ground clearance.

If you are wondering why you will need such a modification, we’ll share with you what a typical lift kit entails and the benefit of having it, in the sections below.

What a typical lift kit includes

Simply put, a lift kit is a kit consisting of a few parts required to lift a particular vehicle model along with instructions on how to perform it. If you’re wondering what is included in a lift kit, take note of the following:

  • Smaller lift kit: This kit is usually designed to attain a three-inch lift by using shock mount spacers that are bolted in place to augment the lift height.
  • Larger, more complete kit: This kit is meant to achieve a three-inch lift and above by using control arms, shock absorbers, and the relocation brackets to install the kit.

Other modifications to consider

There are a few other modifications to consider before thinking about getting a lift kit. Keep in mind that the ride height achieved through the use of a lift kit may impact other areas of the vehicle. Below are other modifications to factor in whenever you consider adding a lift kit:

  • Trailer hitch with hitch step: Installing a trailer hitch with an attachable hitch step will help you get access to the bed of your SUV with ease.
  • Step bumper: As the trailer hitch may be undesirable to the off-road community, you may have rear bumpers configured with hitch steps to offer a benefit on multiple fronts.
  • Side steps: Side steps or running boards can be configured to help you have access to the extended cabin.
  • Differential gears: Lower gears can help restore the loss of power brought by adding bigger tires and a lift, and improve the vehicle’s acceleration.

Why you need a lift kit

Now, let’s take a look at why a lift is important and why it needs to lift a vehicle in the first place. Below are three main reasons to utilize a lift kit for your vehicle:

  • Suspension capabilities: A lift kit can increase the capabilities of the suspension, which can significantly increase ride quality, suspension travel, and durability.
  • Ground clearance: A lift kit can be added with bigger tires that can truly augment the ground clearance. This essentially increases the distance of the vehicle’s body from the terrain below.
  • Wheel fitment: A lift kit can help increase the size of the tire that can be fitted underneath.

Conclusion

Overall, a lift kit is a great modification that helps to increase the vehicle’s height and ground clearance. If you did not know much about lift kits before, we hope that this blog has clarified as to why you have to invest in it for the good of your vehicle and for other uses.

Old diesel trucks never cease to become even more amazing to experience and enjoy as they grow older over the years. From ‘94 7.0-liter Ford Powerstrokes to ‘88 Dodge 12 Valves, the truck models of the past bear a ruggedness to them that contributes to their overall character unlike any other. If you own an old diesel truck, then you’re probably familiar with the appeal of the characteristic styling and driving experience that it bears. Now, as great as it may be to have a piece of automotive history in your garage, however, there’s one question that may cross your mind:

“Am I doing everything that’s necessary to keep it on the road?”

Fortunately, keeping an old diesel truck as roadworthy as possible doesn’t have to be a painstaking process that involves throwing money out of the window. In fact, it’s quite the opposite.

If you want to hit the road with your classic diesel truck and make sure that it serves you well on any drive in the long run, here are three tips that can help it stay in tip-top shape:

1. Invest in quality oil and have it changed on a regular basis

Out of all the different aspects that make classic diesel trucks so unique, the most noteworthy one that any driver should know is that some good oil and a routine change go a long way in keeping its engine primed for performance.

As opposed to regular car engines today that come with many parts that make the entire process of maintaining performance much more complicated, old Cummins, Duramax, and Powerstroke engines are actually straightforward. By simply following your manufacturer’s recommendations, adding in the specified type of oil, and changing it regularly, you can easily keep your old diesel truck running smoothly for many years.

2. Keep an eye out for your engine wear items

When it comes to keeping an old workhorse driving the same way it came out of the factory, it’s important to note that engine wear items play a significant role in how long everything can run smoothly and safely.

Various parts, such as pulley bearings, tensioners, serpentine belts, and water pumps, have specific functions that contribute to the overall performance of a truck. Although these parts may seem quite minor at first, they can make the difference between your truck’s ability in making it to 150,000 miles on an interval or barely making it to 50,000. This is why you should make sure that you get your wear-prone parts checked regularly!

3. Service your truck regularly

If there’s any key to maintaining the longevity of your old diesel truck that would guarantee longevity the most, it would definitely be having it serviced regularly. With a regular maintenance service, you’ll be able to keep your truck in pristine condition by carrying out regular processes, such as spark plug checks, wheel alignment, and soot deposit removals. All these checks will work best for the longevity of your vehicle as well!

Conclusion

When it comes to keeping an old diesel truck running smoothly for many years of happy use, it’s important to note that what you do to keep it in great shape will make a significant difference in its lifespan!

There are good reasons to invest in a diesel truck if you’re on the lookout for a new pick-up truck. For one, this vehicle setup can suit your lifestyle, provide lots of engine power, and probably fit your budget well. Whether you are up for a trip this summer or need a business pick-up this spring, a diesel truck can be your best bet!

What’s great about diesel engines is that they require less maintenance when compared to gasoline-powered vehicles. However, you will want to make sure that the overall efficiency of your diesel truck, and that it will last for as long as possible. That is where vehicle maintenance comes into the picture.

In this article, we will share with you five maintenance tips for your diesel truck to ensure its optimal performance and longevity in the long run:

1. Schedule regular cleaning

As with any type of vehicle, regular cleaning of your diesel truck is a must. It’s best to set a regular schedule for the cleaning of your truck. The goal is to get rid of gunk, as your truck’s parts can get built up with dirt and grime over long periods. The same is true for your fuel that ought to be strictly clean because all these factors can drive high performance and help foster a healthy fuel economy.

2. Be sure to fill up the fluids

Checking up your truck’s fluids and ensuring they are filled up are imperative. Make sure to monitor the acidity of your coolant regularly as well, and change it accordingly. Also, you need to check your oil level and the window washer fluid frequently. All these steps will ensure that your vehicle will run as smoothly as possible, which should be a part of your overall maintenance.

3. Don’t forget to change the filters

Filters play a crucial role in your diesel truck in keeping your engine clean. Typically, new engines may contain two fuel filters. This is why you must make sure to check both regularly and replace them when necessary. Additionally, you will want to set up a routine to change them as scheduled or after every 20,000 kilometers so that the engine’s cleanliness and the vehicle’s overall performance are ensured.

4. Make sure to change the oil regularly

Regularly changing the oil of your diesel truck is a must. As a rule of thumb, change it every 8,000 kilometers. You may need to do so even before reaching this mileage when your engines experience hard-driving and towing. Also, keep in mind that you should only use the right oil for your vehicle by checking the manual so that there are no mixes, leading to inefficient power.

5. Inspect and fix your exhaust system

The exhaust system of your diesel truck is paramount to the overall health of your vehicle. If you experience any issues with your vehicle, address them as soon as possible. Also, be on the lookout for leaks and corrosion and rust inside and outside your exhaust pipe. Ultimately, you have to check the exhaust system regularly so that you won’t have any problems with the truck.

Conclusion

Regular maintenance of your truck should be a part of your usage equation. As outlined above, all it takes is to schedule a regular cleaning, fill up the fluid, change the filters, replace the oil consistently, and fix your exhaust system. All these steps can make a difference in the lifespan of your diesel truck!
